triples.evidence: Today’s lecture is straightforward. We’re going to talk about the concept of a system-a core idea that underpins everything we’ll cover in this course.
To qualify as a linear system, two properties must be satisfied: additivity and homogeneity.
Lastly, we’ll touch on nonlinear systems-which are simply systems that don’t meet these linearity conditions.

evidence: We're going to talk about the concept of a system-a core idea that underpins everything we'll cover in this course.
In this lecture, we'll begin with general systems, then narrow our focus to linear systems-
To qualify as a linear system, two properties must be satisfied: additivity and homogeneity.
Together, these form what we call the superposition principle.
Lastly, we'll touch on nonlinear systems-which are simply systems that don't meet these linearity conditions.

In each chapter, I aim for a balanced structure: we start with three main sections, followed by a concluding section with remarks and points for deeper thought. In this lecture, we’ll begin with general systems, then narrow our focus to linear systems-which, as the name suggests, behave in a straightforward, predictable way, much like linear functions in mathematics.
